awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Novel Ultralight Sensors for Avian Migration and Movement Studies
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of this project is to develop, test, and deploy novel sensors that will enable the study of activity and migration of small songbirds (20-50 grams).  The sensors required for such small animals require  weight and energy budgets (1 gram and 1 micro Watt, respectively) below most low-energy devices and must survive in challenging environments and collect useful data over many months.  This project has the potential to significantly impact the science of animal behavior because many important species cannot be effectively monitored with existing technologies -- for example roughly half of bird species weigh less than 50 grams.

While the focus of this project is to develop the technologies that will enable other researchers to study the behavior of small animals, the project will test these devices on a specific model species (Dark-eyed Juncos) in order to enhance the understanding of the variation of timing on reproduction, migration, and biodiversity. Finally, while the target application for this project is animal biology, many of the fundamental technical problems are common to general low-energy sensing problems.  For example, a key problem is detecting the onset of interesting events using extremely low energy levels prior to expending the significantly higher levels of energy needed to collect high resolution data.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
This was an interdisciplinary project at the intersection of Biology and Computer Science whose goals were to develop and field test sensor payloads (?tags?) to enable novel biological research on the behavior and ecology of small songbirds. The project was designed around three major phases:

  1. the development of an open-source and easily customized hardware/software architecture for sub-gram tags tiny enough for a small songbird to carry safely
  2. field testing of these tags with short to medium term experiments, and
  3. a longer (6-12 month) field experiment involving dozens of animals.

Intellectual merit

The primary activity in this project was the development of  ultra-light (sub-gram), ultra-low power data-loggers (henceforth tags) for collecting behavioral and environmental data on both captive and free-ranging songbirds.  The tags could continuously collect activity data for 4-12 months at 0.5-0.8 grams and collected more than 500,000 hours of data in a variety of experiments.

 The tags use a low-power accelerometer to detect when an animal is active.  In one example we tracked the activity of an American Robin over 10 months and results clearly illustrate a long flight on November 19, 2021 with several return flights in March 2022.

To be useful, the tags required a support ?ecosystem? that enables tag configuration, battery charging, and data recovery. The ecosystem developed under this project was extensible in order to enable the rapid development of tags with other sensors or data collection protocols.  The keys to this extensibility were a flexible software architecture that enables adding new tags to the ecosystem with minimal software development and a hardware architecture that supports rapid prototyping with accurate energy measurement.  

In sum, the project had several significant results:  the creation of an open-source system for creating ultra-light data-loggers, the use of that system to create a sub-gram activity logger, and the use of that logger, by our collaborators, in multiple experiments with a variety of species of song-birds. 

A publication that resulted is Chen, Jiawei, Brown, Geoffrey, Fudickar Adam. 2021. "Simulation-based validation of activity logger data for animal behavior studies.? Animal Biotelemetry 9 (1): 31.

A website with background and figures can be found here. https://geoffreymbrown.github.io/ultralight-tags/

A photo of an example tag is shown.

Broader impacts

The project also provided research experiences for undergraduates and, through our collaborators, the opportunity for post-docs and PhD students to use novel devices in their research.

Bird populations have recently been shown to be in steep decline.  Critical to their protection is knowledge of how their locations vary over the course of the year and learning the connections between winter and summer homes.  The tags produced on this project provide a model for affordable and effective devices for tracking animals year-round.

 

 


Last Modified: 03/19/2023
Modified by: Ellen D Ketterson

Image
  • An example tag created and deployed as part of this project, weighed 0.8g
    Geoffrey Brown
    Ellen D Ketterson
    example tag
